top_categories.workout_context: Big Horn Gravel’s rugged singletrack, alpine mountain roads demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Big Horn Gravel rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Racing Big Horn Gravel isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Big Horn Gravel when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Big Horn Gravel’s rugged jeep roads, singletrack, backcountry dirt and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Big Horn Gravel’s 10,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Big Horn Gravel. Make this intensity feel like home.
At 85 miles, Big Horn Gravel punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Big Horn Gravel — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Every session at Big Horn Gravel intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for Big Horn Gravel’s 10,000ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.
Cadence efficiency makes every pedal stroke at Big Horn Gravel count — smooth technique reduces muscular fatigue over long distances.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Big Horn Gravel’s 85 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Big Horn Gravel with 10,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Dehydration and altitude stress; Long exposure at elevation compounds fatigue.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Big Horn Gravel demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride rugged jeep roads, singletrack, backcountry dirt at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: rugged singletrack, alpine mountain roads, backcountry blm/jeep roads. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 85 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, TT Threshold, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 85 miles of rugged jeep roads, singletrack, backcountry dirt in Gypsum, Colorado.
